segment.source: Overlay tiled images on a map
segment.target: Overlay tiled images on a map

segment.source: Overlay third-party or custom tiled images on a map by using tile sources.
segment.target: Overlay third-party or custom tiled images on a map by using tile sources.

segment.source: Use tile sources to overlay specialized information such as weather data, population data, or seismic data; or use tile sources to replace the default map entirely.
segment.target: Use tile sources to overlay specialized information such as weather data, population data, or seismic data; or use tile sources to replace the default map entirely.

segment.source: Overlay tiled images on a map
segment.target: Overlay tiled images on a map

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Overlay third-party or custom tiled images on a map by using tile sources.
segment.target: Overlay third-party or custom tiled images on a map by using tile sources.

segment.source: Use tile sources to overlay specialized information such as weather data, population data, or seismic data; or use tile sources to replace the default map entirely.
segment.target: Use tile sources to overlay specialized information such as weather data, population data, or seismic data; or use tile sources to replace the default map entirely.

segment.source: Tip To learn more about using maps in your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.
segment.target: Tip To learn more about using maps in your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample

segment.source: Tiled image overview
segment.target: Tiled image overview

segment.source: Map services such as Nokia Maps and Bing Maps cut maps into square tiles for quick retrieval and display.
segment.target: Map services such as Nokia Maps and Bing Maps cut maps into square tiles for quick retrieval and display.

segment.source: These tiles are 256 pixels by 256 pixels in size, and are pre-rendered at multiple levels of detail.
segment.target: These tiles are 256 pixels by 256 pixels in size, and are pre-rendered at multiple levels of detail.

segment.source: Many third-party services also provide map-based data that's cut into tiles.
segment.target: Many third-party services also provide map-based data that's cut into tiles.

segment.source: Use tile sources to retrieve third-party tiles, or to create your own custom tiles, and overlay them on the map displayed in the MapControl.
segment.target: Use tile sources to retrieve third-party tiles, or to create your own custom tiles, and overlay them on the map displayed in the MapControl.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: When you use tile sources, you don't have to write code to request or to position individual tiles.
segment.target: When you use tile sources, you don't have to write code to request or to position individual tiles.

segment.source: The MapControl requests tiles as it needs them.
segment.target: The MapControl requests tiles as it needs them.

segment.source: Each request specifies the X and Y coordinates and the zoom level for the individual tile.
segment.target: Each request specifies the X and Y coordinates and the zoom level for the individual tile.

segment.source: You simply specify the format of the Uri or filename to use to retrieve the tiles in the UriFormatString property.
segment.target: You simply specify the format of the Uri or filename to use to retrieve the tiles in the UriFormatString property.

segment.source: That is, you insert replaceable parameters in the base Uri or filename to indicate where to pass the X and Y coordinates and the zoom level for each tile.
segment.target: That is, you insert replaceable parameters in the base Uri or filename to indicate where to pass the X and Y coordinates and the zoom level for each tile.

segment.source: Here's an example of the UriFormatString property for an HttpMapTileDataSource that shows the replaceable parameters for the X and Y coordinates and the zoom level.
segment.target: Here's an example of the UriFormatString property for an HttpMapTileDataSource that shows the replaceable parameters for the X and Y coordinates and the zoom level.

segment.source: (The X and Y coordinates represent the location of the individual tile within the map of the world at the specified level of detail.
segment.target: (The X and Y coordinates represent the location of the individual tile within the map of the world at the specified level of detail.

segment.source: The tile numbering system starts from {0, 0} in the upper left corner of the map.
segment.target: The tile numbering system starts from {0, 0} in the upper left corner of the map.

segment.source: For example, the tile at {1, 2} is in the second column of the third row of the grid of tiles.)
segment.target: For example, the tile at {1, 2} is in the second column of the third row of the grid of tiles.)

segment.source: For more info about the tile system used by mapping services, see Bing Maps Tile System.
segment.target: For more info about the tile system used by mapping services, see Bing Maps Tile System.

segment.source: Overlay tiles from a tile source
segment.target: Overlay tiles from a tile source

segment.source: Overlay tiled images from a tile source on a map by using the MapTileDataSource.
segment.target: Overlay tiled images from a tile source on a map by using the MapTileDataSource.

segment.source: Instantiate one of the three tile data source classes that inherit from MapTileDataSource.
segment.target: Instantiate one of the three tile data source classes that inherit from MapTileDataSource.

segment.source: HttpMapTileDataSource
segment.target: HttpMapTileDataSource

segment.source: LocalMapTileDataSource
segment.target: LocalMapTileDataSource

segment.source: CustomMapTileDataSource
segment.target: CustomMapTileDataSource

segment.source: Configure the UriFormatString to use to request the tiles by inserting replaceable parameters in the base Uri or filename.
segment.target: Configure the UriFormatString to use to request the tiles by inserting replaceable parameters in the base Uri or filename.

segment.source: The following example instantiates an HttpMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: The following example instantiates an HttpMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: This example specifies the value of the UriFormatString in the constructor of the HttpMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: This example specifies the value of the UriFormatString in the constructor of the HttpMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: Instantiate and configure a MapTileSource.
segment.target: Instantiate and configure a MapTileSource.

segment.source: Specify the MapTileDataSource that you configured in the previous step as the DataSource of the MapTileSource.
segment.target: Specify the MapTileDataSource that you configured in the previous step as the DataSource of the MapTileSource.

segment.source: The following example specifies the DataSource in the constructor of the MapTileSource.
segment.target: The following example specifies the DataSource in the constructor of the MapTileSource.

segment.source: You can restrict the conditions in which the tiles are displayed by using properties of the MapTileSource.
segment.target: You can restrict the conditions in which the tiles are displayed by using properties of the MapTileSource.

segment.source: Display tiles only within a specific geographic area by providing a value for the Bounds property.
segment.target: Display tiles only within a specific geographic area by providing a value for the Bounds property.

segment.source: Display tiles only at certain levels of detail by providing a value for the ZoomLevelRange property.
segment.target: Display tiles only at certain levels of detail by providing a value for the ZoomLevelRange property.

segment.source: Optionally, configure other properties of the MapTileSource that affect the loading or the display of the tiles, such as Layer, AllowOverstretch, IsRetryEnabled, and IsTransparencyEnabled.
segment.target: Optionally, configure other properties of the MapTileSource that affect the loading or the display of the tiles, such as Layer, AllowOverstretch, IsRetryEnabled, and IsTransparencyEnabled.

segment.source: Add the MapTileSource to the TileSources collection of the MapControl.
segment.target: Add the MapTileSource to the TileSources collection of the MapControl.

segment.source: Overlay tiles from a web service
segment.target: Overlay tiles from a web service

segment.source: Overlay tiled images retrieved from a web service by using the HttpMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: Overlay tiled images retrieved from a web service by using the HttpMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: Instantiate an HttpMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: Instantiate an HttpMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: Specify the format of the Uri that the web service expects as the value of the UriFormatString property.
segment.target: Specify the format of the Uri that the web service expects as the value of the UriFormatString property.

segment.source: To create this value, insert replaceable parameters in the base Uri.
segment.target: To create this value, insert replaceable parameters in the base Uri.

segment.source: For example, in the following code sample, the value of the UriFormatString is:
segment.target: For example, in the following code sample, the value of the UriFormatString is:

segment.source: The web service has to support a Uri that contains the replaceable parameters {x}, {y}, and {zoomlevel}.
segment.target: The web service has to support a Uri that contains the replaceable parameters {x}, {y}, and {zoomlevel}.

segment.source: Most web services (for example, Nokia, Bing, and Google) support Uris in this format.
segment.target: Most web services (for example, Nokia, Bing, and Google) support Uris in this format.

segment.source: If the web service requires additional arguments that aren't available with the UriFormatString property, then you have to create a custom Uri.
segment.target: If the web service requires additional arguments that aren't available with the UriFormatString property, then you have to create a custom Uri.

segment.source: Create and return a custom Uri by handling the UriRequested event.
segment.target: Create and return a custom Uri by handling the UriRequested event.

segment.source: For more info, see the Provide a custom URI section later in this topic.
segment.target: For more info, see the Provide a custom URI section later in this topic.

segment.source: Then, follow the remaining steps described previously in the Tiled image overview.
segment.target: Then, follow the remaining steps described previously in the Tiled image overview.

segment.source: The following example overlays tiles from a fictitious web service on a map of North America.
segment.target: The following example overlays tiles from a fictitious web service on a map of North America.

segment.source: The value of the UriFormatString is specified in the constructor of the HttpMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: The value of the UriFormatString is specified in the constructor of the HttpMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: In this example, tiles are only displayed within the geographic boundaries specified by the optional Bounds property.
segment.target: In this example, tiles are only displayed within the geographic boundaries specified by the optional Bounds property.

segment.source: Overlay tiles from local storage
segment.target: Overlay tiles from local storage

segment.source: Overlay tiled images stored as files in local storage by using the LocalMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: Overlay tiled images stored as files in local storage by using the LocalMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: Typically, you package and distribute these files with your app.
segment.target: Typically, you package and distribute these files with your app.

segment.source: Instantiate a LocalMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: Instantiate a LocalMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: Specify the format of the file names as the value of the UriFormatString property.
segment.target: Specify the format of the file names as the value of the UriFormatString property.

segment.source: To create this value, insert replaceable parameters in the base filename.
segment.target: To create this value, insert replaceable parameters in the base filename.

segment.source: For example, in the following code sample, the value of the UriFormatString is:
segment.target: For example, in the following code sample, the value of the UriFormatString is:

segment.source: If the format of the file names requires additional arguments that aren't available with the UriFormatString property, then you have to create a custom Uri.
segment.target: If the format of the file names requires additional arguments that aren't available with the UriFormatString property, then you have to create a custom Uri.

segment.source: Create and return a custom Uri by handling the UriRequested event.
segment.target: Create and return a custom Uri by handling the UriRequested event.

segment.source: For more info, see the Provide a custom URI section later in this topic.
segment.target: For more info, see the Provide a custom URI section later in this topic.

segment.source: Then, follow the remaining steps described previously in the Tiled image overview.
segment.target: Then, follow the remaining steps described previously in the Tiled image overview.

segment.source: You can use the following protocols and locations to load tiles from local storage:
segment.target: You can use the following protocols and locations to load tiles from local storage:

segment.source: Uri
segment.target: Uri

segment.source: More info
segment.target: More info

segment.source: ms-appx:///
segment.target: ms-appx:///

segment.source: Points to the root of the app's installation folder.
segment.target: Points to the root of the app's installation folder.

segment.source: This is the location referenced by the Package.InstalledLocation property.
segment.target: This is the location referenced by the Package.InstalledLocation property.

segment.source: ms-appdata:///local
segment.target: ms-appdata:///local

segment.source: Points to the root of the app's local storage.
segment.target: Points to the root of the app's local storage.

segment.source: This is the location referenced by the ApplicationData.LocalFolder property.
segment.target: This is the location referenced by the ApplicationData.LocalFolder property.

segment.source: ms-appdata:///temp
segment.target: ms-appdata:///temp

segment.source: Points to the app's temp folder.
segment.target: Points to the app's temp folder.

segment.source: This is the location referenced by the ApplicationData.TemporaryFolder property.
segment.target: This is the location referenced by the ApplicationData.TemporaryFolder property.

segment.source: The following example loads tiles that are stored as files in the app's installation folder by using the protocol.
segment.target: The following example loads tiles that are stored as files in the app's installation folder by using the protocol.

segment.source: The value for the UriFormatString is specified in the constructor of the LocalMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: The value for the UriFormatString is specified in the constructor of the LocalMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: In this example, tiles are only displayed when the zoom level of the map is within the range specified by the optional ZoomLevelRange property.
segment.target: In this example, tiles are only displayed when the zoom level of the map is within the range specified by the optional ZoomLevelRange property.

segment.source: Provide a custom URI
segment.target: Provide a custom URI

segment.source: If the replaceable parameters available with the UriFormatString property of the HttpMapTileDataSource or the UriFormatString property of the LocalMapTileDataSource aren't sufficient to retrieve your tiles, then you have to create a custom Uri.
segment.target: If the replaceable parameters available with the UriFormatString property of the HttpMapTileDataSource or the UriFormatString property of the LocalMapTileDataSource aren't sufficient to retrieve your tiles, then you have to create a custom Uri.

segment.source: Create and return a custom Uri by providing a custom handler for the UriRequested event.
segment.target: Create and return a custom Uri by providing a custom handler for the UriRequested event.

segment.source: The UriRequested event is raised for each individual tile.
segment.target: The UriRequested event is raised for each individual tile.

segment.source: In your custom handler for the UriRequested event, combine the required custom arguments with the X, Y, and ZoomLevel properties of the MapTileUriRequestedEventArgs to create the custom Uri.
segment.target: In your custom handler for the UriRequested event, combine the required custom arguments with the X, Y, and ZoomLevel properties of the MapTileUriRequestedEventArgs to create the custom Uri.

segment.source: Return the custom Uri in the Uri property of the MapTileUriRequest, which is contained in the Request property of the MapTileUriRequestedEventArgs.
segment.target: Return the custom Uri in the Uri property of the MapTileUriRequest, which is contained in the Request property of the MapTileUriRequestedEventArgs.

segment.source: The following example shows how to provide a custom Uri by creating a custom handler for the UriRequested event.
segment.target: The following example shows how to provide a custom Uri by creating a custom handler for the UriRequested event.

segment.source: It also shows how to implement the deferral pattern if you have to do something asynchronously to create the custom Uri.
segment.target: It also shows how to implement the deferral pattern if you have to do something asynchronously to create the custom Uri.

segment.source: Overlay tiles from a custom source
segment.target: Overlay tiles from a custom source

segment.source: Overlay custom tiles by using the CustomMapTileDataSource.
segment.target: Overlay custom tiles by using the CustomMapTileDataSource.

segment.source: Create tiles programmatically in memory on the fly, or write your own code to load existing tiles from another source.
segment.target: Create tiles programmatically in memory on the fly, or write your own code to load existing tiles from another source.

segment.source: To create or load custom tiles, provide a custom handler for the BitmapRequested event.
segment.target: To create or load custom tiles, provide a custom handler for the BitmapRequested event.

segment.source: The BitmapRequested event is raised for each individual tile.
segment.target: The BitmapRequested event is raised for each individual tile.

segment.source: In your custom handler for the BitmapRequested event, combine the required custom arguments with the X, Y, and ZoomLevel properties of the MapTileBitmapRequestedEventArgs to create or retrieve a custom tile.
segment.target: In your custom handler for the BitmapRequested event, combine the required custom arguments with the X, Y, and ZoomLevel properties of the MapTileBitmapRequestedEventArgs to create or retrieve a custom tile.

segment.source: Return the custom tile in the PixelData property of the MapTileBitmapRequest, which is contained in the Request property of the MapTileBitmapRequestedEventArgs.
segment.target: Return the custom tile in the PixelData property of the MapTileBitmapRequest, which is contained in the Request property of the MapTileBitmapRequestedEventArgs.

segment.source: The PixelData property is of type IRandomAccessStreamReference.
segment.target: The PixelData property is of type IRandomAccessStreamReference.

segment.source: The following example shows how to provide custom tiles by creating a custom handler for the BitmapRequested event.
segment.target: The following example shows how to provide custom tiles by creating a custom handler for the BitmapRequested event.

segment.source: This example creates identical red tiles that are partially opaque.
segment.target: This example creates identical red tiles that are partially opaque.

segment.source: The example ignores the X, Y, and ZoomLevel properties of the MapTileBitmapRequestedEventArgs.
segment.target: The example ignores the X, Y, and ZoomLevel properties of the MapTileBitmapRequestedEventArgs.

segment.source: Although this is not a real world example, the example demonstrates how you can create in-memory custom tiles on the fly.
segment.target: Although this is not a real world example, the example demonstrates how you can create in-memory custom tiles on the fly.

segment.source: The example also shows how to implement the deferral pattern if you have to do something asynchronously to create the custom tiles.
segment.target: The example also shows how to implement the deferral pattern if you have to do something asynchronously to create the custom tiles.

segment.source: Replace the default map
segment.target: Replace the default map

segment.source: To replace the default map entirely with third-party or custom tiles:
segment.target: To replace the default map entirely with third-party or custom tiles:

segment.source: Specify MapTileLayer.BackgroundReplacement as the value of the Layer property of the MapTileSource.
segment.target: Specify MapTileLayer.BackgroundReplacement as the value of the Layer property of the MapTileSource.

segment.source: Specify MapStyle.None as the value of the Style property of the MapControl.
segment.target: Specify MapStyle.None as the value of the Style property of the MapControl.
